choices.text: Is an abductor of the hip in hip flexion
Passes through the lesser sciatic foramen
Is the preferred site of intramuscular gluteal injection
Passes anterior to the femoral neck

questions.text: What is the function of marked muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscle is Piriformis muscle. It functions as a lateral rotator of the extended thigh and abductor of the flexed thigh at the hip joint.

  • The piriformis muscle originates from the anterior surface of the sacrum and inserts onto the greater trochanter of the femur.
  • It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen and lies posterior to the hip joint.
  • Main Functions:
    • Lateral rotation of the extended thigh
    • Abduction of the thigh when the hip is flexed
    • Helps stabilize the hip joint
  • This function is important in activities like walking, especially when shifting body weight from one leg to the other.

Explanation of other options:

Passes through the lesser sciatic foramen (Option B): The piriformis muscle passes through the greater sciatic foramen, not the lesser; the latter transmits structures like the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels.

Is the preferred site of intramuscular gluteal injection (Option C): The gluteus medius (upper outer quadrant) is the preferred site to avoid injury to the sciatic nerve, not the piriformis.

Passes anterior to the femoral neck (Option D): The piriformis passes posterior to the hip joint and femoral neck, unlike the iliopsoas, which passes anteriorly.

choices.text: The anterior fibres of the gluteus medius and minimus act as medial rotator of the hip joint
The gluteus maximus is the most powerful lateral rotator of the hip joint
Gluteus medius and minimus are supplied by the inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
The superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5,S1) emerges from the greater sciatic notch

questions.text: Regarding the hip joint all of the following statements are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gluteus medius and minimus are actually supplied by the superior gluteal nerve, not the inferior gluteal nerve.

  • The hip joint is a ball-and-socket synovial joint formed between the head of the femur and the acetabulum of the pelvis.
  • Multiple muscles act around the joint to produce movements like flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation.
  • Gluteus medius and minimus:
    • These are key abductors and medial rotators of the hip. (Option A ruled out)
    • They are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (roots: L4, L5, S1).
  • Gluteus maximus:
    • This is the largest and strongest muscle of the gluteal region and is the primary extensor and lateral rotator of the hip. (Options B ruled out)
  • The superior gluteal nerve exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, superior to the piriformis muscle. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Femoral
Saphenous
Sciatic
Popliteal

questions.text: The longest single nerve in the body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The sciatic nerve is the longest single nerve in the body, extending from the pelvis to the foot.
  • The sciatic nerve, derived from the lumbosacral plexus (L4–S3), is the largest and longest nerve in the human body.
  • It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen below the piriformis muscle and travels down the posterior thigh, where it innervates all the hamstring muscles (except the short head of biceps femoris) and then splits at the popliteal fossa into:
    • Tibial nerve - supplies posterior leg and plantar foot
    • Common fibular nerve - supplies anterior/lateral leg and dorsum of foot
  • Because of its length from the lower spine to the sole, it is vulnerable to compression or injury (e.g., in sciatica).

Explanation of other options:

Femoral (Option A): The femoral nerve innervates the anterior thigh and ends before the knee; it is not as long as the sciatic nerve.

Saphenous (Option B): A sensory branch of the femoral nerve, it is the longest cutaneous nerve, but not the longest single nerve.

Popliteal (Option D): There is no nerve named "popliteal nerve"; this refers to a region (popliteal fossa) where the sciatic nerve divides.

choices.text: The common peroneal nerve slopes downwards lateral to the biceps tendon
The sural nerve is a cutaneous branch of the common peroneal nerve
The middle genicular artery of the popliteal artery supply the cruciate ligaments
The popliteus muscle is supplied by a branch of the common peroneal nerve

questions.text: Regarding the popliteal fossa, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The middle genicular artery, a branch of the popliteal artery, penetrates the capsule of the knee joint to supply the cruciate ligaments and synovium.

  • The popliteal fossa is a diamond shaped depression behind the knee joint with four borders.
  • These borders are formed by the muscles in the posterior compartment of the leg and thigh:
    • Superomedial - semimembranosus.
    • Superolateral - biceps femoris.
    • Inferomedial - medial head of the gastrocnemius.
    • Inferolateral - lateral head of the gastrocnemius and plantaris.
  • The floor of the popliteal fossa is formed by the posterior surface of the knee joint capsule, popliteus muscle and posterior femur.
  • The roof is made of up two layers:
    • Popliteal fascia and skin.
    • The popliteal fascia is continuous with the fascia lata of the leg.
  • Contents of popliteal fossa:
    • Tibial nerve: Through the fossa , Most superficial
    • Common peroneal nerve: Lateral
    • Popliteal artery: Deepest
  • Cruciate ligaments receive their blood supply from the middle geniculate artery (branch of popliteal artery).

choices.text: Knee
Shoulder
Hip
Wrist

questions.text: The largest ball and socket joint in the body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hip joint is the largest ball-and-socket joint in the body, providing both mobility and stability.

  • The hip joint is a multiaxial synovial ball-and-socket joint formed between the head of the femur and the acetabulum of the pelvis.
  • It is designed to bear body weight and allow a wide range of motion including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, and circumduction.
  • Compared to the shoulder (another ball-and-socket joint), the hip is deeper and more stable due to the bony configuration and strong surrounding ligaments and muscles.
  • This structural depth contributes to its ability to support the body's weight during standing, walking, and running.

choices.text: Superior gluteal nerve
Obturator nerve
Femoral nerve
Sciatic nerve

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child with a history of poliomyelitis presents with difficulty stabilizing the pelvis while walking, although Trendelenburg's test is negative. On further examination, you notice wasting of thigh muscles-especially on the medial side-and weakness in hip adduction. There is no pelvic drop during single-leg stance.
Which nerve is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Weakness of hip adduction with an intact Trendelenburg test suggests injury to the obturator nerve.

  • The obturator nerve innervates the adductor compartment of the thigh (adductor longus, brevis, magnus, gracilis, obturator externus).
  • In poliomyelitis or direct nerve injury, hip adduction is weakened, but Trendelenburg's test remains negative as hip abductors (gluteus medius and minimus)-supplied by the superior gluteal nerve are unaffected.
  • Thus, no pelvic drop is seen, differentiating it from superior gluteal nerve injury.

Explanation of other options:

Superior gluteal nerve (Option A): Injury causes weakness of gluteus medius and minimus leading to a positive Trendelenburg sign (pelvic drop on contralateral side during single leg stance), not a negative test.

Femoral nerve (Option C): Innervates the anterior thigh compartment, especially the quadriceps femoris, affecting knee extension, not hip adduction.

Sciatic nerve (Option D): Supplies posterior thigh and all muscles below the knee; injury causes knee flexion weakness and foot drop, not isolated adductor paralysis.

choices.text: Pectineus - Obturator nerve
Gracilis - Femoral nerve
Sartorius - Femoral nerve
Adductor magnus (hamstring part) - Obturator nerve

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly paired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sartorius is correctly paired with the femoral nerve, which supplies it.

  • The sartorius muscle is part of the anterior compartment of the thigh and is supplied by the femoral nerve. It
  • It is a long, strap-like muscle that aids in flexing, abducting, and laterally rotating the thigh, as well as flexing the knee.
  • Pectineus is primarily innervated by the femoral nerve, though it may receive a branch from the obturator nerve (dual innervation). (Option A ruled out)
  • Gracilis is part of the medial compartment and is innervated by the obturator nerve, not the femoral. (Option B ruled out)
  • The hamstring part of the adductor magnus is innervated by the tibial division of the sciatic nerve, not the obturator nerve. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Is where the inguinal ligament is attached to the fascia lata
Is where the external oblique aponeurosis is joined to Scarpa's fascia
Is where Scarpa's fascia is attached to the fascia lata
Is mainly supplied by the femoral nerve

questions.text: The skin crease of the hip:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hip skin crease marks the line where Scarpa's fascia fuses with the fascia lata, preventing fluid spread into the thigh.

  • Scarpa fascia is a membranous layer of superficial fascia that extends over the lower thoracic and anterior abdominal wall, anterior to the midaxillary lines.
  • Here, fibrous septa of subcutaneous tissue are condensed beneath the fat into a thin but strong membrane.
  • The fascia allows the subcutaneous fat (Camper fascia) to slide freely over the underlying thoracic wall, rectus sheath, and external oblique aponeurosis.
  • Superiorly and laterally, Scarpa fascia fades out over the upper thoracic wall and midaxillary lines.
  • Medially and inferiorly it fades into linea alba and the pubic symphysis.
  • Just below the inguinal ligament in the upper thigh, it blends into the fascia lata.
  • It is continuous with the superficial fascia of the perineum (Colles fascia) and of the penis, scrotum and labia (Dartos fascia)

Fascia lata

  • The fascia lata is the deep fascia of the thigh, forming a tough outer sleeve around the muscles.
  • Scarpa's fascia, the deep membranous layer of superficial fascia in the lower anterior abdominal wall, fuses with the fascia lata just inferior to the inguinal ligament, at the level of the hip skin crease.
  • This anatomical fusion is clinically significant—it prevents urine or fluid from a ruptured urethra from tracking into the thigh; instead, the fluid accumulates in the superficial perineal or abdominal regions.
  • Attachments of fascia lata include:
    • Superiorly: inguinal ligament, iliac crest, sacrum, coccyx, sacrotuberous ligament, ischial tuberosity, and pubis.
    • Laterally: forms the iliotibial tract, extending to the lateral condyle of the tibia.
    • Inferiorly: continues with deep fascia of the leg (crural fascia).

Explanation of other options:

Is where the inguinal ligament is attached to the fascia lata (Option A): Incorrect. The inguinal ligament attaches to the ASIS and pubic tubercle; not directly to the fascia lata.

Is where the external oblique aponeurosis is joined to Scarpa's fascia (Option B): Incorrect. External oblique aponeurosis contributes to the inguinal canal and anterior abdominal wall, but does not join Scarpa's fascia at the hip crease.

Is mainly supplied by the femoral nerve (Option D): Incorrect. The skin over the hip crease is supplied mainly by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves, not the femoral nerve.

choices.text: The arterial supply comes mainly from the inferior gluteal artery
The artery to the head assumes importance after age of 7 years
Psoas lies posterior to the hip joint
The anterior division of the obturator nerve gives partial supply to the hip joint

questions.text: With regard to the head of the femur:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior division of the obturator nerve contributes sensory innervation to the hip joint via its articular branch.

  • The hip joint receives innervation from multiple nerves:
    • Femoral nerve (via the nerve to rectus femoris)
    • Obturator nerve (primarily the anterior division)
    • Sciatic nerve (occasionally)
    • Superior gluteal nerve
    • Nerve to quadratus femoris
  • The anterior division of the obturator nerve gives an articular branch that passes through the obturator foramen to innervate the inferomedial part of the joint capsule.
  • This nerve can be a source of referred pain in hip pathology.
  • The blood supply to the femoral head primarily comes from:
    • Medial circumflex femoral artery (major source via retinacular branches)
    • Lateral circumflex femoral artery
    • Obturator artery (via the artery to the head of the femur, important in children)
    • Inferior gluteal artery (contributes minimally)

Explanation of other options:

The arterial supply comes mainly from the inferior gluteal artery (Option A): Incorrect. The medial circumflex femoral artery is the main supply, not the inferior gluteal artery.

The artery to the head assumes importance after age of 7 years (Option B): Incorrect. The artery to the head of the femur (from obturator artery) is crucial before age 7; after that, its contribution diminishes as epiphyseal vessels regress.

Psoas lies posterior to the hip joint (Option C): Incorrect. The psoas major lies anterior to the hip joint and crosses it obliquely.

choices.text: Tibial and femoral nerve > Popliteal vein > Popliteal artery > Popliteal lymph nodes
Popliteal lymph nodes > Popliteal vein > Popliteal artery > Tibial and femoral nerve
Tibial and femoral vein > Popliteal vein > Popliteal artery > Popliteal lymph nodes
Tibial and femoral nerve > Popliteal artery > Popliteal vein > Popliteal lymph nodes

questions.text: How are the contents of the popliteal fossa arranged from deep to superficial?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

From superficial to deep, the order in the popliteal fossa is nerve → vein → artery → lymph nodes.

  • In the popliteal fossa, the anatomical arrangement of neurovascular structures (from superficial to deep) is essential for clinical assessments and surgical interventions.
  • The typical arrangement is:
    • Tibial nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve)
    • Popliteal vein
    • Popliteal artery
    • Popliteal lymph nodes (which lie deeper in the fat surrounding the vessels)
  • This NVB orientation is clinically important in procedures like popliteal fossa exploration or nerve blocks.
  • The tibial nerve is the most superficial, followed by the popliteal vein (which lies between the nerve and artery), and the popliteal artery is the deepest structure against the femur.
  • Lymph nodes lie deep and lateral in the fat.

choices.text: It forms part of the blood supply of the femoral head along with the cruciate anastomosis and the ligamentum teres.
The medial circumflex femoral artery and the lateral circumflex femoral artery form a ring around the femoral neck.
The ascending branches of these two arteries then form an anastomosis with the descending branch of the superior gluteal artery.
The ascending branches of these two arteries then form an anastomosis with the descending branch of the inferior gluteal artery.

questions.text: What is NOT true about Trochanteric anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trochanteric anastomosis involves the superior gluteal artery, not the inferior gluteal artery.

  • The trochanteric anastomosis is a crucial vascular network that supplies the head of the femur, especially in adults where the ligamentum teres artery becomes less significant. (Options A ruled out)
  • It is formed primarily by:
    • Ascending branches of the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries (branches of profunda femoris artery), (Option B ruled out)
    • Descending branch of the superior gluteal artery (a branch of internal iliac artery). (Option C ruled out)
  • These vessels encircle the base of the femoral neck, ensuring a collateral supply to the retinacular arteries, which enter the femoral head along the neck.
  • The inferior gluteal artery is involved in the cruciate anastomosis, not the trochanteric one.

choices.text: This overlies the saphenous opening in the fascia lata
It is pierced by the great saphenous vein and lymphatic vessels draining into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes
The term "cribriform" refers to sieve-like structures with multiple perforations, derived from the Latin cribrum
It covers the fossa ovalis located in the leg overlying the popliteal fossa

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the structure shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given structure is cribriform fascia. The fossa ovalis (saphenous opening) is located in the thigh, not the leg or popliteal fossa.

  • The cribriform fascia (also called fascia cribrosa or Hesselbach’s fascia) is a sieve-like layer of superficial fascia that covers the saphenous opening (also called fossa ovalis) in the upper thigh, just below the inguinal ligament. (Options A ruled out)
  • It allows passage of the great saphenous vein, superficial arteries, and lymphatic vessels as they enter deeper structures like the femoral vein and lymph nodes. (Option B ruled out)
  • The term "cribriform" refers to sieve-like structures with multiple perforations, derived from the Latin cribrum. (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: The lymph node found at the femoral canal, anterosuperior to the femoral vein, is known as Cloquet's node.
Cloquet's node, the nexus between the deep inguinal and iliac/obturator lymph nodes
These lymph nodes drain the glans clitoris in females, and the glans penis and the distal part of the spongy urethra in males.
The inferior-most lymph node is termed the node of Cloquet

questions.text: What is not true regarding Cloquet's nodes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cloquet's node is the superior-most deep inguinal lymph node, not the inferior-most.

  • Cloquet's node, also known as the Rosenmüller node, is the uppermost of the deep inguinal lymph nodes, lying in the femoral canal just medial to the femoral vein. (Option A ruled out)
  • It acts as a link between the deep inguinal nodes and the external iliac nodes, hence serving as a key station for the spread of cancers from the lower limb or perineum. (Option B ruled out)
  • It drains structures such as:
    • Glans penis and distal urethra in males (Option C ruled out)
    • Glans clitoris and vulva in females
    • Lower anal canal and perianal region

choices.text: 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c
1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b
1-c, 2-d, 3-b, 4-a
1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

questions.text: Match the following ligaments:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Each ligament listed has a well-known eponymous synonym

1. Inguinal ligament : Poupart's ligament

It's the inferior border of the aponeurosis of the external oblique, stretching from ASIS to the pubic tubercle. Known classically as Poupart's ligament.

2. Iliopectineal ligament : Cooper's ligament

This is a thickening of the periosteum along the pectineal line, posterior to the inguinal ligament, used in hernia repair.

3. Lacunar ligament : Gimbernat ligament

Triangular expansion from the inguinal ligament that connects to the pubic bone, forms the medial boundary of the femoral ring.

4. Round ligament : Fillmore's ligament

Passes through the inguinal canal and attaches to labia majora; maintains uterine anteversion.

choices.text: Superior gluteal nerve, L4, L5, S1
Superior gluteal nerve, L3, L4, S1
Inferior gluteal nerve, L4, L5, S1
Inferior gluteal nerve, L3, L4, S1

questions.text: Which nerve supplies the marked muscles A and B?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked muscles are Gluteus minimum , gluteus medius respectively which is supplied by superior gluteal nerve which originate from L4, L5, S1.

  • The gluteal region is supplied by two primary nerves arising from the sacral plexus:
    • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1):
      • Emerges above the piriformis muscle through the greater sciatic foramen.
      • Innervates:
        • Gluteus medius
        • Gluteus minimus
        • Tensor fasciae latae
      • These muscles are primarily responsible for hip abduction and medial rotation. Damage to this nerve results in a positive Trendelenburg sign (pelvic drop on the unsupported side).
    • Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2):
      • Emerges below the piriformis.
      • Innervates: Gluteus maximus, which is the major extensor of the hip.
      • Damage causes weakness in rising from sitting, climbing stairs, and running.
  • Thus, since the marked muscles are likely gluteus medius and minimus, they are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1).

choices.text: Piriformis
Superior gamellus
Obturator externus
Inferior gamellus

questions.text: Mark the incorrect muscle:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscles marked as C is Obturator internus

  • In the gluteal region, the lateral rotators of the hip include:
    • Piriformis (originates from sacrum)
      • Runs from anterior sacrum through the greater sciatic foramen to the greater trochanter.
    • Superior and inferior gemellus (above and below obturator internus tendon)
      • Superior gemellus located just superior to the tendon of obturator internus.
      • Inferior gemellus found just inferior to obturator internus.
    • Obturator internus (runs through lesser sciatic foramen and inserts into greater trochanter)
  • The obturator externus, in contrast, lies anterior to the hip joint and is not visible in a posterior dissection of the gluteal region.
  • Therefore, a muscle labeled as Obturator externus in this view is misidentified, and it is actually obturator internus.

choices.text: A
B
C
D

questions.text: A patient with a complaint of atraumatic hip, thigh, or knee pain, which may be associated with limping or an inability to bear weight. He is diagnosed with slipped capital femoral epiphysis and a lurching gait. Which marked nerve is involved here?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lurching gait in slipped capital femoral epiphysis is due to weakness of hip abductors, indicating involvement of the superior gluteal nerve, marked as B in the image.

  • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) commonly affects adolescents and presents with:
    • Hip, thigh, or knee pain
    • Limping or Trendelenburg gait
    • Decreased internal rotation and abduction at the hip
  • The Trendelenburg gait results from weakness of the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, which stabilize the pelvis during walking.
  • These muscles are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1).
  • Injury or dysfunction of this nerve leads to the inability to abduct the thigh, resulting in pelvic drop on the opposite side during single-leg stance and compensatory lurching gait to the affected side.
  • Thus, the structure labeled B corresponds to the superior gluteal nerve.

choices.text: Flexion and abduction
Abduction and external rotation
Extension and lateral rotation
Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation

questions.text: What is the action of muscle in the attachment marked below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the posterior surface of the femur, and the structure marked is gluteal tuberosity, to which the gluteus maximus muscle is attached. It causes extension and lateral rotation at the hip joint.

  • The gluteus maximus inserts into the gluteal tuberosity of the femur and the iliotibial tract.
  • This muscle is:
    • The largest and most superficial gluteal muscle
    • A powerful extensor of the hip joint (especially from a flexed position)
    • Also functions in lateral (external) rotation of the thigh
  • This is particularly important during climbing, rising from a seated position, and running.
  • The attachment point marked on the image corresponds to the gluteal tuberosity, a rough ridge on the posterior femur, where part of the gluteus maximus tendon inserts.

Explanation of other options:

Flexion and abduction (Option A): These are actions of tensor fasciae latae or sartorius, not gluteus maximus.

Abduction and external rotation (Option B): Abduction is mainly done by gluteus medius and minimus, not maximus.

Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation (Option D): While gluteus maximus does extend and laterally rotate, it does not adduct; in fact, it may assist in abduction via the iliotibial tract.

choices.text: Gluteus minimus
Gluteus medius
Piriformis
Iliacus

questions.text: Which muscle is not attached to the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the greater trochanter and Iliacus is not attached to it.

Greater trochanter:

  • The marked area on the image corresponds to the greater trochanter of the femur, a major bony prominence on the lateral aspect of the proximal femur.
  • Muscles inserted into it are:
    • Gluteus minimus (Option A ruled out)
    • Gluteus medius (Option B ruled out)
    • Piriformis (Option D ruled out)
    • Common tendon of obturator internus and gamelli.
    • Lesser trochanter: It is a conical projection of the shaft present posteromedially. Muscles inserted to it are iliacus and psoas major.

Iliacus

  • The iliacus, on the other hand, is part of the iliopsoas muscle group and inserts on the lesser trochanter, located medially and posteriorly on the femur. 
  • Its action is hip flexion, not abduction or rotation.

choices.text: Inferior gluteal nerve
Sciatic nerve
Superior gluteal nerve
Obturator nerve

questions.text: A patient presents with Lower back pain, Buttock pain, Leg pain, Chronic tension/tightness; also known as tight hamstrings, Lower leg pain, Tingling and Pins & Needles sensation. The patient was later diagnosed with spinal cord degeneration. Entrapment of nerves is shown in the image below. Which nerve is it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and its compression/entrapment causes a classic pattern of posterior thigh and leg pain with paresthesia, often seen in spinal pathologies.

  • The sciatic nerve arises from L4-S3 and exits the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen, typically below the piriformis muscle.
  • It supplies:
    • Motor innervation to posterior thigh and all leg and foot muscles (via tibial and common fibular branches)
    • Sensory innervation to most of the leg and foot (except medial leg)
  • Compression of the sciatic nerve, as in spinal degeneration or piriformis syndrome, can cause:
    • Back pain radiating to the buttock and posterior leg
    • Hamstring tightness
    • Tingling/numbness in the leg or foot
    • Foot drop (if common fibular branch affected)

Explanation of other options:

Inferior gluteal nerve (Option A): Supplies gluteus maximus; injury leads to weakness in hip extension, but not sensory symptoms in the leg.

Superior gluteal nerve (Option C): Innervates gluteus medius, minimus, and TFL; injury causes Trendelenburg gait, not posterior leg pain or tingling.

Obturator nerve (Option D): Supplies medial thigh adductors; entrapment causes groin and medial thigh pain, not buttock/posterior leg symptoms.
